dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2023, the public transport situation in Almaty was just a total disaster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty twenty three, the public transport situation in Almaty was just a total disaster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Public transport of Almaty is just a disastrous.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, those Chinese buses are struggling with, what was it, like 650,000 daily passengers?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, those Chinese buses are struggling with, what was it, like six hundred fifty thousand daily passengers?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinese buses can barely cope with the 600,000 daily passenger traffic, BAKAD is struggling, LRT tender lasting already fourth years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the LRT tender has been dragging on for five years already. It's just not moving.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the L R T tender has been dragging on for five years already. It's just not moving.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinese buses can barely cope with the 600,000 daily passenger traffic, BAKAD is struggling, LRT tender lasting already fourth years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, the metro construction is so slow—only about two stations every four years. Compare that to Moscow building, uh, 26 stations by 2024.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, the metro construction is so slow-only about two stations every four years. Compare that to Moscow building, uh, twenty six stations by twenty twenty four.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Average historical tempo of Almaty Metro construction is about 2 stations every 5 years, just for comparison, Moscow will build 25 metro stations by 2024, 8-9 new stations will be commissioned annually, the second large metro circle line is nearing completion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and Almaty's metro ring plan is ambitious but makes a lot of sense. They want to connect existing railways to form a 52-kilometer circle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and Almaty's metro ring plan is ambitious but makes a lot of sense. They want to connect existing railways to form a fifty two-kilometer circle.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The total length of Almaty metro ring will be 50 km and 28 stations, including 13 underground and 15 ground stations along railway tracks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: With 30 stations, half underground and half above ground. That would handle over 300,000 passengers a day.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: With thirty stations, half underground and half above ground. That would handle over three hundred thousand passengers a day.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The total length of Almaty metro ring will be 50 km and 28 stations, including 13 underground and 15 ground stations along railway tracks. The passenger traffic of the ring circled metro will be about 300 thousand passengers per day, or 50% of the total public passenger traffic of Almaty.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is more than half of all public transport traffic in the city. And it's way cheaper than digging new tunnels everywhere.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is more than half of all public transport traffic in the city. And it's way cheaper than digging new tunnels everywhere.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The passenger traffic of the ring circled metro will be about 300 thousand passengers per day, or 50% of the total public passenger traffic of Almaty. Metro ring circle construction would require less investment, as existing operable railway lines around Almaty are already connecting stations Almaty-2, Almaty-1, Burundai and Heat power station TEZ-2.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Because they can use the rail lines that are already there, like around Almaty-2 and TEZ-2.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because they can use the rail lines that are already there, like around Almatyminus two and TEZminus two.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Metro ring circle construction would require less investment, as existing operable railway lines around Almaty are already connecting stations Almaty-2, Almaty-1, Burundai and Heat power station TEZ-2.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, connecting Raimbek station to Almaty-1 via existing tracks is a no-brainer. They just need to add double tracks and electrify.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, connecting Raimbek station to Almatyminus one via existing tracks is a no-brainer. They just need to add double tracks and electrify.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, it would be more rational to use existing railway track along Suyunbai Avenue, expanding it with double track insertion and electrifying within metro third rail solution.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And it's a common practice in places like Europe and Japan—integrating metro and commuter rail.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's a common practice in places like Europe and Japan-integrating metro and commuter rail.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Combination of railway and metro lines is usual good practice in Europe, Japan, Russia and China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It would really link up those suburban districts too, like Kalkaman and Burunday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It would really link up those suburban districts too, like Kalkaman and Burunday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Such a rail circle will unite densely populated suburban districts of Almaty like Kalkaman, Terekty, Algabas, Industrial zone, Shanyrak, Burunday and Almaty-1, which become new recreation areas of the future Almaty.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I heard they're planning to finish Kalkaman and Western Station by late 2026, which gets them closer to that full circle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I heard they're planning to finish Kalkaman and Western Station by late twenty twenty six, which gets them closer to that full circle.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the city's plans, construction of the metro stations Kalkaman and Western station next to Altyn Orda market, is going to be completed by the end of 2025.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But it all depends on cooperation between the Akimat and KTZ. Without that, it's just plans on paper.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it all depends on cooperation between the Akimat and K T Z. Without that, it's just plans on paper.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Technical implementation of metro ringing is only possible by close cooperation between Akimat and KTZ.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And if they modernize the stations properly, it could really transform those areas into recreation zones.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And if they modernize the stations properly, it could really transform those areas into recreation zones.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Same for the future new ground-based metro stations Baum Grove, Burundai, Industrial zone, Heat power station TEZ-2, which will improve the areas and recreational zones around metropolitan stations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Still, it's a huge undertaking. Moscow's ring moves half a million people daily—Almaty's current metro only does 42,000.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, it's a huge undertaking. Moscow's ring moves half a million people daily-Almaty's current metro only does forty two thousand.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: An interesting fact, the Moscow Metro Ring Line of 12 stations, 19 km long, has traffic of 540 thousand passengers per day. Almaty half-ring metro of 9 stations, 11 km long carries in average 40 thousand passengers per day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, so this ring could be a game-changer, if they ever get it done.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, so this ring could be a game-changer, if they ever get it done.

artist_script:
HostA: Back in 2023, the public transport situation in Almaty was just a total disaster.
HostB: Yeah, I mean, those Chinese buses are struggling with, what was it, like 650,000 daily passengers?
HostA: Exactly. And the LRT tender has been dragging on for five years already. It’s just not moving.
HostB: Meanwhile, the metro construction is so slow—only about two stations every four years. Compare that to Moscow building, uh, 26 stations by 2024.
HostA: Right, and Almaty’s metro ring plan is ambitious but makes a lot of sense. They want to connect existing railways to form a 52-kilometer circle.
HostB: With 30 stations, half underground and half above ground. That would handle over 300,000 passengers a day.
HostA: Which is more than half of all public transport traffic in the city. And it’s way cheaper than digging new tunnels everywhere.
HostB: Because they can use the rail lines that are already there, like around Almaty-2 and TEZ-2.
HostA: Plus, connecting Raimbek station to Almaty-1 via existing tracks is a no-brainer. They just need to add double tracks and electrify.
HostB: And it’s a common practice in places like Europe and Japan—integrating metro and commuter rail.
HostA: It would really link up those suburban districts too, like Kalkaman and Burunday.
HostB: I heard they’re planning to finish Kalkaman and Western Station by late 2026, which gets them closer to that full circle.
HostA: But it all depends on cooperation between the Akimat and KTZ. Without that, it’s just plans on paper.
HostB: For sure. And if they modernize the stations properly, it could really transform those areas into recreation zones.
HostA: Still, it’s a huge undertaking. Moscow’s ring moves half a million people daily—Almaty’s current metro only does 42,000.
HostB: Yeah, so this ring could be a game-changer, if they ever get it done.
